text:
In this video, you’ll see how to manage AWS 
support cases with Atlassian Jira Service Management.

With this solution, you can send and 
receive support cases between the

services using request forms that can be 
customized for more accurate correspondence,

and synchronize case communication 
with the AWS Support Center.
We’ll begin in the Jira console,

where we’ll open the AWS Service 
Management Connector page.

The AWS Accounts tab is where 
you connect your accounts.

For our purposes, we already have 
a few connected AWS accounts.
Let’s view the Connector settings.
There are several AWS services enabled by default.
To configure AWS Support, select AWS Support.
Let’s look at the AWS Support configuration.

This is where you link Jira 
projects to AWS accounts.

In this example, both of our AWS accounts 
are associated with our Test-Jira project.

Let’s save the settings, which will begin the 
synchronization of the enabled services.

We can now generate AWS support cases 
from the Jira Service Management Console.
Let's create a new issue.
Our associated project is the default.

We have both the issue type and 
request type set to AWS Support Case.

Let’s summarize the issue and 
then add a brief description.
Next, we’ll rate the priority.

We’ll need to select the AWS 
account the issue is associated with.

Finally, we’ll specify the AWS service 
and category, and create the issue.

When the issue is submitted, an AWS 
Case ID is created automatically.

Let's navigate to the AWS 
Support Center to find it.
The issue appears in our list of active cases.
Let’s reply to the issue.

We can respond through 
the web, by chat, or by phone.

To add the response to Jira Service 
Management, we must use the Web contact method.
Let’s submit our correspondence.

Now let's return to the project in Atlassian 
Jira Service Management to see the response.

Here’s the response from the 
AWS Support Center Console.

We can add an internal note that will 
only be seen here and not sent to AWS.

Now, let’s reply to the customer with 
the issue and include an attachment.

This reply method has a bi-directional synch 
between AWS and JIRA Service Management.
We’ll include a screenshot.
Let’s save the reply.

Now let’s return to the AWS support 
console and view our support cases.
We’ll select the case we created.

The record includes all the 
correspondence for this issue.

Notice that the internal note we saved in
Jira Service Management did not come over.

Now, let’s access the same project 
through Jira Service Management.

This time, we’ll go to 
Channels and open the Help Center.

This landing page can be 
configured by the Jira admin.

Let’s select AWS Requests and 
create a new AWS Support Case.

Jira admins can configure this request 
form to include more specific fields.
To do that, let’s switch to the Jira console.

We’ll navigate to Project 
settings and select Request types.

Under Unassigned request types, 
we’ll select AWS Support Case.

We can click and drag the non-required 
fields to add or remove them from the form.

For our purposes, we’ll discard the 
changes and continue with the default form.

Let’s return to Jira Service Management 
and fill in the request form.

The request to initiate a 
support case has been sent.

Now let’s go to the AWS Support Center 
and view the support case that was created.
Notice that the case has been given a Case ID.
Let’s resolve the case.
The case now has a status of “Resolved."

Switching to Jira Service Management, we can 
see that the support ticket notes this status change.

In the Jira help center, we see the same 
comment stating the case has been resolved.

Next, we’ll resolve a ticket from 
the Jira Service Management.

Let’s filter for issues to 
show only AWS Support Cases.
We’ll select the one we want to resolve.

Let’s change the ticket status 
from “Open” to “Resolved.”

Now we’ll specify the resolution 
and resolve the issue.
The ticket is now resolved.

Let’s return to the AWS Support Center 
and refresh the list of support cases.

The status has automatically updated 
to show the issue is now resolved.

You’ve just seen how to manage AWS support 
cases with Atlassian Jira Service Management.

You can learn more about this topic in 
the description and links for this video.
Thanks for watching. Now it’s your turn to try.
